pyLib.train package¶

Submodules¶

pyLib.train.MoM module¶

MoM.py

Utility functions for mixture of models

class pyLib.train.MoM.MoMNet(clus, mdls)[source]¶

Bases: torch.nn.modules.module.Module

A network architecture that my mom told me

cuda()[source]¶

Moves all model parameters and buffers to the GPU.

This also makes associated parameters and buffers different objects. So it should be called before constructing optimizer if the module will live on GPU while being optimized.

Arguments:
device (int, optional): if specified, all parameters will be
copied to that device
Returns:
Module: self
forward(x)[source]¶

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overriden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

getClusY(x)[source]¶

Take x as input, return prediction of y from classifier

getPredY(x)[source]¶

Take x as input, return predicted y, I do not take care of xScale or yScale since I do not know it

getPredYi(x, i)[source]¶

Take x as input, use the i-th regressor to predict y.

getWeights()[source]¶
numModel[source]¶
parameters()[source]¶

Returns an iterator over module parameters.

This is typically passed to an optimizer.

Yields:
Parameter: module parameter
Example:
>>> for param in model.parameters():
>>>     print(type(param.data), param.size())
<class 'torch.FloatTensor'> (20L,)
<class 'torch.FloatTensor'> (20L, 1L, 5L, 5L)
pyLib.train.MoM.momLoader(model, withclus=False, argmax=False)[source]¶

Given a model name, usually a pickle file, load the model, create a function. It is loading mom, so it returns both predY and y, the first is used to recover classification

pyLib.train.dataLoader module¶

Here contains my own implementation of dataLoader. It is based on torch, but finely tuned for my usage.

Bases: torch.utils.data.dataloader.DataLoader

Slightly different dataLoader from built-in one by PyTorch It supports getNumData and negative batch_size(means all)

class pyLib.train.dataLoader.labelFactory(fnm, nameLblPair, xfun=None, scalex=True)[source]¶

Bases: pyLib.train.dataLoader.Factory

For classification task, we have a bunch of labelled data, use this to manage those. We support two modes, one given file, we use a list of keys and functions operated on. Another mode is to simply add data label by label.

pyLib.train.torchUtil module¶

Utility functions combined with pytorch Such as define a mlp network relying on a list of numbers

Bases: torch.nn.modules.module.Module

eval(x)[source]¶

Sets the module in evaluation mode.

This has any effect only on modules such as Dropout or BatchNorm.

forward(x)[source]¶

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overriden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

pyLib.train.torchUtil.cplxModelLoader(model, name0='model', name1='vNets', name2='classNet')[source]¶

Given a complex model name, usually a pickle file, load all the net models, create a function. Based on design of architecture, cplxModel does not have to normalize data It returns many functions that can be directly called!!!

pyLib.train.torchUtil.encoderLoader(model, name='model', reScale=True, cuda=False, return_encoder=False, return_decoder=False)[source]¶

Read the autoEncoder and return two functions

pyLib.train.torchUtil.funGen(net, xScale=None, yScale=None, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Give a net, we use scales to get a function

pyLib.train.torchUtil.model2cpu(model, name='model', ptmode=False, statedict=False)[source]¶

Given a model name, convert all necessary stuff into cpu version

pyLib.train.torchUtil.modelLoader(model, name='model', reScale=True, cuda=False, ptmode=False, statedict=False, size=None)[source]¶

Given a model name, usually a pickle file, load the model, create a function. New argument: reScale, which reads xmean, xstd, umean, ustd from file and properly rescale things It returns a function that can be called using !!!RAW!!! data

pyLib.train.torchUtil.modelLoaderV2(model, cudafy=False, ptmode=False)[source]¶

Given a model name, usually a pickle file, load the model. Return a tuple of net and xScale It returns the raw Net and corresponding xScale and yScale

Load a svm

pyLib.train.train module¶

Train a neural network to approximate the function, which is y = f(x, o) where x is the collision trajectory, o is obstacle, and y is another collision-free traj We hope we can directly learn the map so a good initial guess can be provided for later use

pyLib.train.train.evalOne(config, x, cuda=False)[source]¶

Load a model from config, evaluate the model on data x.

Parameters:
  • config – dict, from calling genTrainConfig
  • x – ndarray, input to the model
  • cuda – bool, if we enable cudaify of the model
pyLib.train.train.genFromDefaultConfig(**kwargs)[source]¶

Generate a default configuration dict to avoid things.

Available keywords include: network: a list of int, describing network structure lr: float, learning rate, default 1e-3 epoch: int, number of learning epoch, default 1500 batch_size: int, size of minibatch for sgd, default 64 test_batch_size: int, size of minibatch for evaluating test set; -1 means all, default -1 errorbackstep: int, if test error has no improvement within this steps, quit training, default 300 epochbackstep: int, if test error has no improvement within this epoch, quit training, default 10 trainsize: float, split of training and test set size, default 0.8 recordfreq: int, frequency of recording of test errors, default 10 namex: str, key that maps to input, default ‘x’ namey: str, key that maps to output, default ‘y’ ourdir: str, directory to store saved models, default ‘models’ outname: str, name for this particular model, default ‘y_of_x.pt’ dataname: str, name for the data, might be unnecessary, default ‘data/data.npz’

pyLib.train.train.getFileName(basename, prename, obj)[source]¶
pyLib.train.train.trainAutoEncoder(net, data, config, seed=1994, scale=False)[source]¶

Train an autoencoder, an unsupervised learning model.

The net has to be encoded by the user, if it is None, and config has network size we explore GaoNet to do this.

net : nn.Module object, the network to be trained config : dict, containing training parameters data : dict, containing data for training seed : int, seeder for random scale : if we scale the data to make it normal

pyLib.train.train.trainOne(config, data, scale_back=False, seed=None, is_reg_task=True, x0_name='x0', net=None, scalex=True, scaley=True)[source]¶

Train a network and save it somewhere.

It handles naive regression and classification task if GaoNet is used. Training hyperparameters are listed in config, which is a dictionary Data is a dictionary, for regression task, it has at least two entries, specified by config For classification task, it has keys like x0/x1, etc. each is another dict that has x0_name as key or ndarray

config : dict, containing training parameters data : dict, containing data for training scale_back : bool, if we calculate smooth L1 loss in original scale (default False) seed : int, seeder for random is_reg_task : bool, if we are training a regression task instead of classification x0_name : str, the name of x in each cluster when classification task is performed net : a nn.Module object, if it is used, we do not construct GaoNet scalex : bool, if we standarize x before training scaley : bool, if we standarize y before training

class pyLib.train.train.trainer(net, trainLder, testLder, trainloss, testloss=None, gtfun=<built-in function gt>, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

A base class for trainer. The user has to provide a trainSet and testSet, a net, a fun for loss, and other setting

pyLib.train.weighttrain module¶

Train a neural network to approximate the function

The loss is scaled, the weight is passed in using vecKeyFactory
